answers.answerText: C. Right and left homonymous defects
answers.explanation: This visual field defect has a bilateral homonymous appearance. If one looks at the right side of the visual field, they are similar in both eyes. In a similar manner, the left side of the visual field has an identical appearance in both eyes.

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
OCT RNFL and ganglion cell analysis (GCA) was performed and is shown below:

![](/content/media/neuro_op_31_2.webp)

What pattern of changes is demonstrated by the GCA?

answers.answerText: B. Right and left homonymous thinning OU
answers.explanation:
This GCA demonstrates homonymous thinning bilaterally. In other words, the pattern of thinning is highly similar in both maculae. 

GCA can be particularly useful in the evaluation of visual field defects, especially in the context of poor visual field testing. Lesions involving the retrochiasmal visual pathways (e.g., due to stroke) can result in retrograde degeneration of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), and this is manifested in this patient by GCA thinning. The pattern of GCA thinning corresponds well to the visual field defect because the topographic organization of RGCs is maintained in the setting of retrograde degeneration.

answers.answerText: C. Normal OD and superotemporal thinning OS

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What was the most likely cause of this patient’s VF defect?

answers.explanation: The presence of bilateral homonymous visual field defects indicates involvement of the retrochiasmal visual pathways on both sides of the brain. In the majority of cases, infarction of the visual pathways on both sides is due to a cardiac source. This may include atrial fibrillation or infections such as bacterial endocarditis. Other potential causes include demyelination that may involve the optic tracts on both sides.
